text: our generations response to this
challenge will be judged by history or
if we fail to meet it boldly swiftly and
together we risk consigning future
generations to an irreversible
catastrophe this is neil mcfarland
united nations bureau chief for The New
York Times on Tuesday morning there was
an unprecedented leaders from around the
world for a climate summit at the United
Nations the Secretary General Ban
ki-moon called a meeting because the
climate talks for a global agreement on
reducing pollution and greenhouse gases
has stalled they're basically hoping
that by having all the presidents and
leaders in the same building talking
about it for a day but they can get
political momentum going which has been
lacking up to now the morning started
with speeches and then it's going to
break into sort of seminar sessions all
day where the leaders sit around tables
and talks but in terms of actual content
of the speeches a lot of leaders
restated their positions but they also
stated a commitment to change and a
commitment to try and get an agreement
president who Jintao of China who's the
first leader of his country ever to come
to United Nations to address the General
Assembly said that China was you know
committed to trying to green its economy
and he also said they would cut
emissions by 2020 but he didn't give a
specific number we will vigorously
develop renewable energy at nuclear
energy we will endeavor to increase the
share of non-fossil fuels in primary
energy consumption to around fifteen
percent by 2020 President Obama also
reiterated his position in the position
of his administration that they want to
cut greenhouse grasses in the United
States but he you know acknowledged the
political reality he said we're all
going to face difficulties in our
capitals it is work that will not be
easy as we head towards Copenhagen there
should be no illusions that the hardest
part of our journey is in front of us we
seek sweeping but necessary change in
the midst of a global recession where
every nation's most immediate priority
is reviving their economy and putting
their people back to work a bill has
passed the House of Representatives that
targets a kind of 70
% by 2020 but it's probably going to be
cut when it goes to the Senate and more
important the Senate hasn't taken action
yet it's all been stuck behind the
health care legislation and you know the
president didn't say exactly when he
would engage but he did commit today
that he was going to be involved in that
battle and also you know there were a
lot of other leaders from around the
world speaking the president of Maldives
in the Indian Ocean which is threatened
with sort of being drowned if the if
global warming causes the Seas derives
he said that developing nations should
be committed to mandatory targets and
that's that's a step forward from that
part of the world because the argument
by developing nations has always been
that you know the first world calls this
problem all the pollution in the
atmosphere is from your
industrialization so you should both
help us you know develop green economies
and you should also pay for the damage
that you've caused already
